nexttext: or any $x_1, \dots , x_n$ in $X$, $y_1, \dots , y_n$ in $\mathcal{Y}$ and $n \geq 1$. Given $x \in X$, $K_x : \mathcal{Y} \rightarrow \mathcal{F}(X,\mathcal{Y})$ denotes the linear operator whose action on a vector $y \in \mathcal{Y}$ is the function $K_{xy} \in \mathcal{F}(X,\mathcal{Y})$ defined by
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sum_{i,j=1}^{n}\langle K(x_{i},x_{j})y_{j},y_{i}\rangle\geq 0" display="block"><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></munderover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>j</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>j</mi></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>

prevtext: or any $x_1, \dots , x_n$ in $X$, $y_1, \dots , y_n$ in $\mathcal{Y}$ and $n \geq 1$. Given $x \in X$, $K_x : \mathcal{Y} \rightarrow \mathcal{F}(X,\mathcal{Y})$ denotes the linear operator whose action on a vector $y \in \mathcal{Y}$ is the function $K_{xy} \in \mathcal{F}(X,\mathcal{Y})$ defined by
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="(K_{xy})(t)=K(t,x)y\qquad t\in X." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="F(x)-F(y)=\langle F,M_{x,y},\mathcal{H}\rangle\qquad\forall x,y\in X,\forall F%
\in\mathcal{H}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>M</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℋ</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>∀</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℋ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $\Vert . \Vert_V$ denotes the norm on $V$. Every Banach space has a compatible semi-inner product.
Let $[., .]_V$ be a compatible semi-inner product on $V$. Then one sees by the Cauchy-Schwartz inequality
that for each $f \in \mathcal{B}$, the linear functional $f^*$ on $V$ defined by
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="[f,f]_{V}^{1/2}=\|f\|_{V}\qquad\forall f\in V," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mi>V</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mo>∥</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>∥</mo></mrow><mi>V</mi></msub></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mrow><mo>∀</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi>V</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: is bounded on $V$. In other words, $f^*$ lies in the dual space $\mathcal{B}^â$ of $\mathcal{B}$. Moreover, we have

nexttext: We call $\mathcal{B}$ a $\Lambda$-valued RKBS on $X$ if both $\mathcal{B}$ and $\Lambda$ are uniform and $\mathcal{B}$ is a Banach space of functions from $X$ to $\Lambda$ such that for every $x \in X$, the point evaluation $\delta_x : \mathcal{B} \rightarrow \lambda$ defined by
prevtext: Let $\Lambda$ be a Banach space. A space $\mathcal{B}$ is called a Banach space of $\Lambda$-valued functions on $X$ if it consists of certain functions from $X$ to $\Lambda$ and the norm on $\mathcal{B}$ is compatible with point evaluations in the sense that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\|f\|_{B}=0\Longleftrightarrow f(x)=0\quad\forall x\in X." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>∥</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>∥</mo></mrow><mi>B</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>⟺</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><mrow><mo>∀</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: We call $\mathcal{B}$ a $\Lambda$-valued RKBS on $X$ if both $\mathcal{B}$ and $\Lambda$ are uniform and $\mathcal{B}$ is a Banach space of functions from $X$ to $\Lambda$ such that for every $x \in X$, the point evaluation $\delta_x : \mathcal{B} \rightarrow \lambda$ defined by
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\delta_{x}(f):=f(x),\qquad f\in\mathcal{B}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:=</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="22.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℬ</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\zeta_{x,y}(f):=f(y)-f(x),\qquad\forall f\in\mathcal{B}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ζ</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="22.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>∀</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℬ</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="M_{x_{1},x_{2}}(t)+M_{x_{2},x_{3}}(t)=M_{x_{1},x_{3}}(t)\qquad\forall x_{1},x_%
{2},x_{3},t\in X." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>M</mi><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>M</mi><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>M</mi><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo>∀</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
